Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CyberSEES: Type 1: A Pilot Study on Cognitive Acoustic Underwater Networks (CAUNet) for Sustainable Ocean Monitoring and Exploration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Environmental awareness is a key to sustainable ocean monitoring and exploration. To meet the ever growing requirements of the ocean monitoring and exploration applications, and to preserve a sustainable blue ocean for next generations, a cognitive acoustic underwater network (CAUNet) that is aware of the coexistence of multiple underwater acoustic systems will be designed. The project goals include investigating acoustic spectrum usage via data collection and analysis, designing algorithms, software and hardware for acoustic spectrum sensing and spectrum management, and evaluating the feasibility and performance of the proposed work via simulations, and lab and field experiments.

This project will make significant contributions to the underwater network research community by improving the efficiency of UANs while making them more environmentally friendly. The research activities in this project also provide a rich environment and platform that can facilitate educating and training students from high school to graduate level and inspire students in underrepresented groups to pursue research in science and engineering. Moreover, this project will motivate and enable a wide range of research and outreach activities within the underwater communications, networking, engineering, and marine science communities, and promote progress towards practical solutions in diverse aquatic applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vast yet largely unexplored ocean has fascinated generations of human beings. To meet the ever growing communication needs of the ocean monitoring, exploration and exploitation, the technology of underwater acoustic networks has emerged as a promising technology in recent years. However, existing underwater acoustic networks use the communication channel resources in a static way: they do not change communication frequency band dynamically, leading to inefficient acoustic spectrum usage issue; they do not take into accounts other man-made acoustic sources, creating high interferences in water; they do not consider the activities of marine animals, causing eco-friendliness issue.


Therefore, how to adopt a new technology to explore and exploit the ocean in sustainable ways becomes the subject of this project. We proposed a new concept called the Underwater Cognitive Acoustic Network (UCAN), which incorporates environmental awareness as well as efficient acoustic spectrum usage into the design of underwater acoustic networks. In this project, we explored a three pronged approach for improving on mitigation of underwater communication on marine life and endangered species that occupy the world’s oceans.


The first step of the approach involved the characterization of marine species and their use of the underwater acoustic bandwidth in underwater environments such as the Long Island Sound, where we collected acoustic signals and evaluated the bandwidth usage. From the data, we discovered some interesting acoustic patterns in the 30-50kHz frequency range as well as 100kHz. Our study indicates that the former is likely to be from some marine animals, while the latter seems to be originated from man-made devices, such as depths sounding instrument equipped by commercial and private ships. According to other study, harbor seals could detect acoustic signals up to 100kHz. So the data from the acoustic data logger indicated that the Long Island Sound is home to many marine animals and the human activities could indeed affect a very large population of marine lives. This confirmed our premises in the original grant proposal.


With the discovery from the first step, it is imperative for the underwater acoustic networks to timely and efficiently sense the acoustic channel so that strategies could be made to avoid unnecessary interference between marine animal, human applications (commercial and military) and other noise present in these environments. To achieve the goal, it is necessary to differentiate signals from various sources (e.g. marine animal, ocean noise, acoustic communication signal, etc.). So in the second step of the project, by further studying the data collected from the first step, we discovered that by calculating the cyclostationary based time-smoothed cyclic cross periodogram, the differences of the signal become more obvious. This finding pointed out a way of efficient and effective acoustic spectral sensing. 

Based on the findings in the first two steps, adaptive algorithms and mitigation techniques were then developed to address proper bandwidth utilization and ad-hoc adaptation needed to prevent disastrous effects on marine ecosystems while providing robust and efficient acoustic communications. In the third step of the project, we proposed a novel acoustic spectrum manage scheme, RISM (Receiver-Initiated Spectrum Management), for underwater cognitive acoustic networks. The mitigation technique features joint power and channel optimization so that the acoustic spectrum could be utilized in friendly and efficient ways, especially when there are marine animals around. We also designed an adaptive algorithm which actively predicts the traffic in the network and smartly performs data polling to improve the efficiency of network data transmission. These designs made RISM an eco-friendly scheme. Our study also showed that it outperformed other methods in terms of network throughput, end to end delay and control packets overheads. In addition to RISM, we investigated in the multiple access problem in UCAN. We designed a new protocol with a dynamic control channel to mitigate interferences so that the network throughput and energy efficiency could be improved. Different from many other multi-channel MAC protocols, which assume a static and pre-allocated control channel, we proposed a new method which can dynamically increase or decrease the acoustic bandwidth allocated to the control channel. Preliminary results showed promising performance.


In summary, this pilot study proposed the concept of underwater cognitive acoustic networks, laying the foundation for eco-friendly and sustainable underwater communication and networking. We have investigated in three major research thrusts, including the acoustic spectrum usage, acoustic spectrum sensing and acoustic spectrum management. The research results have been presented in international conferences and published in academic journals. An increasing number researchers in the community of underwater acoustic communication and networking have recognized this new research direction. The research activities conducted in this project could advance the knowledge and technologies to better protect the environment while enabling unprecedented progresses towards robust and efficient communications in the underwater environment.
